{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3130156,"name":"WarrenR","username":"warren.reynolds1","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/a8b319/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T00:04:05.504Z","cooked":"

This question is about the Problems section, down in bottom window in VSCode where it has
Problems, OUTPUT, Debug Console, Terminal. With a bubble number next to Problems. I assume this VSCode trying to identify potential Syntax Problems in your code.

Here is my scenario.
Fresh install of WPILib.
Create new Project
CPP, Example Code, SwerveControllerCommand.
Select the Folder to store the code in
Entry the Team Number
Create the Project.

Initial build that happens when you create a new project builds perfectly, No Problems at this point.
Then you double click on all the files in File explorer to load them into the VSCode window to start looking at the sample project files to see how this project works. As soon as you start looking at the source, everything starts turning red and the problems start counting up.
For this project the count is shown below.
DriveSubsystem.cpp 7 Problems
DriveSubsystem.h 6 Problems
SwerveModule.h 3 Problems
Constants.h 2 Problems

If you run a refresh intellisense, the problems disappear, until you look at the code by clicking on the file name to find it in the window. Then everything turns red and problems come back.

If you run a Build, It builds Successfully and the problems all disappear until you look at the code again and the problems re appear again.

I’ve always taught to fix the errors one at a time from the top of the list of compile errors as often by fixing the first error other errors go away. I assume this approach doesn’t work with “problems” as the errors are listed in File Order in the directory structure.

So what’s the story, Do you just ignore these “problems” as long as it builds OK or is there actually something wrong, that should be fixed so VSCode is happy?
Or is this an actual syntax problem with the WPILib Sample Code for SwerveControllerCommand?

warren.reynolds1:

Do you just ignore these “problems” as long as it builds OK

Yes. Intellisense has limitations that cause it to sometimes fall over and fail to fully parse the complex code that underlies some of the WPILib math libraries. If your code builds, you’re good.

Hi Peter,
Thanks for the quick response.

That’s not the answer I was hoping for. I was hoping for you need to “#include ABC in file XYZ” and they will all go away.

It looks like I’ll just have to live with it and tell the students to take those warnings with a grain of salt.

warren.reynolds1:

Do you have any resources on how you set this up?

  1. Install this VS Code extension: clangd - Visual Studio Marketplace
  2. Run ./gradlew generateCompileCommands.
  3. Copy the compile_commands.json out of the build folder and into the project root if the clangd extension doesn’t pick it up in its original location.

Peter_Johnson:

If your code builds, you’re good.

Are all the WPILib samples actually tested to run on a RoboRIO or are they only tested to see if they compile?

The reason I ask is, if I build and deploy SwerveControllerCommand onto a RoboRIO, the robot code light on driver station never turns green. So I assume the code is crashing on startup on the RoboRIO.

The RIOlog window doesn’t give you anything other than

Info roboRIO: Game data update “” received by Robot

If I Build and Deploy the “Motor Control” example everything is good. ie Robot Code is green in Driver Station. So I assume this would rule out any Issue with the RoboRio Image as it runs other sample code.

Could there be something wrong in the WPILib Libraries to do with the Swerve Drive stuff or Swerve Odometry stuff that is causing the code to crash. I know the odometry has been rewritten to take in distances travelled instead of commanded velocities on the swerve modules. Could this be a potential point to start looking as to why the code is crashing.

Has anyone else been able to get the SwerveControllerCommand code to build-Deploy-Run in 2023?

Info copied from Driver Station about Versions of things.
DS: 23.0
RIO: FRC_roboRIO_2023_v3.1
Lib: C++ 2023.2.1
Pigeon: 22.0 (Phoenix 5)
PDP: 1.40 (Phoenix 5)
CANCoder: 22.0.1.2 (Phoenix 5)
Talon FX: 22.1.1.0 (Phoenix 5)
Free RAM (MB): 45
Free Disk (MB): 226

NB: I have installed Phoenix v5 onto this laptop but It’s not included as a vendor Dep when I compiling the SwerveControllerCommand Example.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2023-01-20T01:37:15.716Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":62,"readers_count":61,"score":42.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":423968,"topic_slug":"should-you-ignore-vscode-c-problems-if-your-code-builds-ok","display_username":"WarrenR","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/should-you-ignore-vscode-c-problems-if-your-code-builds-ok/423968/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3130279,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-01-20T02:30:49.404Z","cooked":"
warren.reynolds1:

Are all the WPILib samples actually tested to run on a RoboRIO or are they only tested to see if they compile?

No, they are not all individually tested to run on the roboRIO. We’re trying to get some testing for some examples in place, but it takes a lot of time.

If its crashing, running in Sim should also crash, and its often easier to debug in sim.

I just double checked, and in this case its something wrong with the ADXRS450_Gyro class when there is no device hooked up. We’ll look into this to see what is going wrong. Theoretically it should work if you actually have an ADXRS450 gyro hooked up.

warren.reynolds1:

That’s not the answer I was hoping for. I was hoping for you need to “#include ABC in file XYZ” and they will all go away.

If you add the following to the top of files with the intellisense problems, they should go away:

+#if __INTELLISENSE__
+#ifdef __ARM_NEON
+#undef __ARM_NEON
+#endif
+#ifdef __ARM_NEON__
+#undef __ARM_NEON__
+#endif
+#endif
